Don't know if anyone is reading this, but here's another tip- never dilute concentrated aqueous acid by simply adding water to it! Instead, add water to your beaker (or whatever type of equipment you're using) first and THEN pipette the acid into it. Otherwise, the first few droplets of water might react and heat up very quickly and end up splashing and causing burns. Be safe and stay curious!

The eye wash can be improved by using a reservoir of non-chlorinated water that first gets used before using the tap water. The workers should be encouraged to try the eye wash in a safety drill. Then, if they have the experience of not getting chlorine sting in their eyes, they would be more likely to use the wash should an emergency arise.

The same anti-aversion conditioning should be used with the whole-body wash. It should shower the user in comfortably warm water, and again the workers need to be baptized in advance. In that way, the user will be more willing to use it, won't be shocked by it, and will stay under longer.
Hank forgot to mention that you should keep the door locked. In that way, you buy yourself a few extra minutes to flush the evidence when the cops break the door down.

Small note, if you do happen to need to pour something slowly, don't hesitate to use a glass rod to help you in not dribbling it down the side of the container.

Put the glass rod in the thing you are pouring into and pour the liquid down the side of the glass rod and it will guide the liquid where it needs to go, overcoming the surface tension in the process. Particularly good for liquids that adhere to glass, like Water and anything dissolved in that water.

In this video we will learn about how to avoid the injury in the lab and some good techniques for using laboratory equipment correctly. What we learn from this video are how is proper lab attire, how to disposing chemical safely, how to avoiding common lab accident properly, what is hazmat diamond, and what is MSDS. The first important thing that must you keep on laboratory is your hair. If your hair is long, it shall always be up in the lab because if is not, it will catch on fire, it also will knock stuff over and intrude your vision. The second one is about our clothes. Clothes must be covered on all your body much as possible usualy we use lab coat and we must use socks and gloves. As we know that our eyes are the most vulnerable organs, we must protect it with eye protector but is not an eyeglasses. And when you feel like something must gotten in your eyes, you might wash your eyes with eye washer. Next is do not eat or drink in the lab because the chemical probably gets in your foods, or you accidentally pick up in the wrong cup, it will be danger for your body. If you are working with any machinery or hazardous substances, you must know about the chemical and you must know about Hazmat Diamond and it good some useful information in its each little box. It’s rated 0 to 4 blue is for healt, red is for flamability, and yellow is for chemical reactivity. If you ever need to know more about a chemical and what it might due to you or to the world. The is a good MSDS that it means the material safety things that it might due to you. If you ever need to find one really fast you dont need to go to the cabinet anymore you can just google friend there will be information on how best to threat the person who got exposed. Always read the MSDS before you even touch a chemical. Also you should probably assumed that every liquid in the lab that is not water and is flammable. From this video we also can learn about a fume hoods. The fuction is to sucks all the air in there out so you dont have to breathe whatever going on in there it is also why its impossible to heating units are constanly pumping in controlled air and and these are contstantly sucking it out. So if you doing some chemistry that might containt goes on in here. Dont try to sucking air that contain in this thing, because it can make headache, nausea, disorientation, dizziness, pulmonary edema and death. Also never test something by testing it. And we must avoid pipete chemical by mouth. Pipetting is one way to move a substance from one testing tube to another. If you want to pour you can pour, you will not overcome the surface tension and it dribble down the side of container, so just commit. Next thing is about cleaning broken glass. We must cleaning up broken glass with a broom, do not with your hands and then deposit the result into a bin specifically for sharp stuff. When your done with an experiment do not approved by the person in a charge of chemical safety. If we throw it on sink it will be dangerous to environment. So from this video we can conclude that safety in laboratory is very important to us.

I took an advanced chem lab, and had to use HCl gas. The cylinder was in a hood, hooked up to an Erlenmeyer flask with a rubber stopper, so I could use a syringe to get the gas out of the flask. The hood used sliding glass panels, and I damn near forgot to close it. But at the last minute I did, and it was a good thing too, because when the gas was turned on the rubber stopper flew off the flask. I would have been covered in HCl gas. 
So, 2 lessons: CLOSE THE HOOD, and TAPE DOWN RUBBER STOPPERS.

When making your own large open cell lead acid batteries for a 240v building UPS system, always remember to correctly  hook up the polarities. Failing to do so may result in the sulfuric acid in your 11th battery flash boiling and spraying onto you. If enough sprays on you, this may even allow your array to discharge through your HAND, causing you a combination heat/acid/electrical burn.

On second thought, don't make your own large scale batteries.

Crashcourse Physics:  The buckling strength of a column is inversely proportional to the length of the column squared.  That means when a long thin thing in compression is twice as long, it's 4 times as weak.  If it is 10 times as long then it is 100 times as weak, and so on.  That's why you hold the glass rod as close to the rubber stopper as possible.

OSHA is in the process of implementing the United Nations Globally Harmonized System of Classification and Labelling of Chemicals (GHS).  Everyone is supposed to be trained by the end of the year and all companies are supposed to be compliant by 2015. Material Safety Data Sheets (MSDs) will be called just Safety Data Sheets (SDSs) and GHS approved labels will be used rather than the NFPA you showed or HMIS labels. Just a heads up that you might want to update that information soon.

Quick fix for destroying that surface tension: put a thin rod over the top of the container and pour along the rod (glass stirring rods work well). Surface tension will instead follow the rod to its tip, taking the liquid wherever you want it to go! This way allows you to pour really slowly if you only need a little bit, or happen to be a timid lab user.

These guidelines are no joke: also bear in mind that your school/university may be more slackadaisacal about these guidelines than you ought to be. The U.S. Chemical Safety Board did a review a few years ago following multiple high-profile accidents in university labs, and long story short: don't count on your school/employer to make sure you're following guidelines, or to even have proper ones in the first place. See CSB's website re: the Texas Tech explosion.
